fields.name: Python Programming
fields.description: Learn Python from basics to advanced

fields.title: Hello World
fields.code: print("Hello, World!")

fields.title: Variables and Data Types
fields.code:
# Variables
name = "Alice"
age = 25
height = 5.7
is_student = True

# Data Types
print(type(name))    # <class 'str'>
print(type(age))     # <class 'int'>
print(type(height))  # <class 'float'>
print(type(is_student))  # <class 'bool'>
fields.description: Variable declaration and basic data types

fields.title: Control Flow
fields.code:
# If-else statement
age = 18
if age >= 18:
    print("You are an adult")
else:
    print("You are a minor")

# For loop
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)

# While loop
count = 0
while count < 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

fields.title: Lists Operations
fields.code:
# Creating lists
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# Accessing elements
print(fruits[0])  # apple
print(fruits[-1]) # cherry

# Modifying lists
fruits.append("orange")
fruits.insert(1, "grape")
fruits.remove("banana")

# List comprehension
squares = [x**2 for x in numbers]
print(squares)  # [1, 4, 9, 16, 25]

fields.title: Dictionaries
fields.code:
# Creating dictionaries
person = {
    "name": "Alice",
    "age": 25,
    "city": "New York"
}

# Accessing values
print(person["name"])  # Alice
print(person.get("age"))  # 25

# Modifying dictionaries
person["email"] = "alice@example.com"
person["age"] = 26

# Dictionary methods
del person["city"]
print(person.keys())   # dict_keys(['name', 'age', 'email'])
print(person.values()) # dict_values(['Alice', 26, 'alice@example.com'])

fields.title: Function Definition
fields.code:
# Simple function
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("Alice"))  # Hello, Alice!

# Function with default parameters
def greet_person(name, greeting="Hello"):
    return f"{greeting}, {name}!"

print(greet_person("Bob"))  # Hello, Bob!
print(greet_person("Bob", "Hi"))  # Hi, Bob!

# Function with multiple return values
def get_user_info():
    name = "Alice"
    age = 25
    return name, age

user_name, user_age = get_user_info()
print(f"{user_name} is {user_age} years old")
fields.description: Function definitions with various parameter types

fields.title: Modules and Imports
fields.code:
# Importing modules
import math
import random as rnd
from datetime import datetime

# Using module functions
print(math.sqrt(16))  # 4.0
print(rnd.randint(1, 10))  # Random number between 1-10
print(datetime.now())  # Current date and time

# Creating a custom module (in separate file)
# my_module.py
def add_numbers(a, b):
    return a + b

def multiply_numbers(a, b):
    return a * b

# Importing from custom module
from my_module import add_numbers, multiply_numbers

print(add_numbers(5, 3))  # 8
print(multiply_numbers(5, 3))  # 15

fields.title: Class Definition
fields.code:
class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age
    
    def greet(self):
        return f"Hello, my name is {self.name} and I am {self.age} years old."
    
    def have_birthday(self):
        self.age += 1
        return f"Happy birthday! Now I'm {self.age} years old."

# Creating objects
person1 = Person("Alice", 25)
person2 = Person("Bob", 30)

print(person1.greet())  # Hello, my name is Alice and I am 25 years old.
print(person2.greet())  # Hello, my name is Bob and I am 30 years old.

print(person1.have_birthday())  # Happy birthday! Now I'm 26 years old.
fields.description: Simple class with constructor and method

fields.title: Inheritance
File Reading
fields.code:
# Reading a text file
try:
    with open("example.txt", "r") as file:
        content = file.read()
        print(content)
        
        # Reading line by line
        file.seek(0)  # Reset file pointer
        for line in file:
            print(line.strip())
            
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("File not found")
except IOError:
    print("Error reading file")

# Reading with context manager (automatic file closing)
with open("example.txt", "r") as file:
    lines = file.readlines()
    print(f"File has {len(lines)} lines")

fields.title: File Writing
fields.code:
# Writing to a file
with open("output.txt", "w") as file:
    file.write("Hello, World!\n")
    file.write("This is a new line.\n")

# Appending to a file
with open("output.txt", "a") as file:
    file.write("This line is appended.\n")

# Writing multiple lines
lines = ["Line 1", "Line 2", "Line 3"]
with open("output.txt", "w") as file:
    for line in lines:
        file.write(line + "\n")

# Using writelines
with open("output.txt", "w") as file:
    file.writelines([line + "\n" for line in lines])

fields.title: Exception Handling
Custom Exceptions
NumPy Arrays
fields.code:
import numpy as np

# Creating arrays
arr1 = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
arr2 = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])
zeros = np.zeros((3, 3))
ones = np.ones((2, 4))
random_arr = np.random.rand(3, 3)

print("1D Array:", arr1)
print("2D Array:")
print(arr2)
print("Zeros array:")
print(zeros)

# Array operations
print("Sum:", np.sum(arr1))  # 15
print("Mean:", np.mean(arr1))  # 3.0
print("Max:", np.max(arr1))  # 5

# Array indexing and slicing
print("First element:", arr1[0])  # 1
print("Last element:", arr1[-1])  # 5
print("First three elements:", arr1[:3])  # [1 2 3]
print("Even indices:", arr1[::2])  # [1 3 5]

fields.title: Requests Library
fields.code:
import requests

# GET request
response = requests.get('https://api.github.com/user', auth=('user', 'pass'))
print(response.status_code)
print(response.headers['content-type'])

# POST request
data = {'key': 'value'}
response = requests.post('https://httpbin.org/post', json=data)
print(response.json())

# Handling errors
try:
    response = requests.get('https://httpbin.org/status/404')
    response.raise_for_status()  # Raises an HTTPError for bad responses
except requests.exceptions.HTTPError as err:
    print(f'HTTP error occurred: {err}')
except requests.exceptions.RequestException as err:
    print(f'Request error occurred: {err}')

# Using sessions for multiple requests
with requests.Session() as session:
    session.auth = ('user', 'pass')
    session.headers.update({'User-Agent': 'MyApp/1.0'})
    
    response = session.get('https://api.github.com/user')
    print(response.json())
fields.description: HTTP requests with the requests library

fields.title: PEP 8 Style Guide
fields.code:
# Good naming conventions
class UserAccount:
    def __init__(self, user_name, user_email):
        self.user_name = user_name
        self.user_email = user_email

    def get_user_info(self):
        return f"{self.user_name} ({self.user_email})"

# Bad naming (avoid)
class useraccount:
    def __init__(self, username, useremail):
        self.username = username
        self.useremail = useremail

    def getuserinfo(self):
        return f"{self.username} ({self.useremail})"

# Proper indentation and line length
def calculate_total_price(items, tax_rate=0.08, discount=0):
    """
    Calculate total price including tax and discount.
    
    Args:
        items (list): List of item prices
        tax_rate (float): Tax rate as decimal (default 8%)
        discount (float): Discount amount (default $0)
    
    Returns:
        float: Total price after tax and discount
    """
    subtotal = sum(items)
    tax_amount = subtotal * tax_rate
    total = subtotal + tax_amount - discount
    return round(total, 2)

# Usage
prices = [10.99, 5.49, 8.75]
total = calculate_total_price(prices, tax_rate=0.1, discount=2.00)
print(f"Total: ${total}")
fields.description: PEP 8 compliant code style and documentation

fields.title: Matplotlib Plot
fields.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
y = [2, 4, 6, 8, 10]

plt.plot(x, y)
plt.xlabel("X-axis")
plt.ylabel("Y-axis")
plt.title("Simple Line Plot")
plt.show()
